actions-list.header: On motion to recommit Roll Call 434
actions-list.actionItem: Yea and Nay vote pending.

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 4790 — "To amend the Federal securities laws with respect to the materiality of disclosure requirements, to establish the Public Company Advisory Committee, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: (Roll no. 433).
On motion to recommit Failed by the Yeas and Nays: (Roll no. 432).

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 3724 — "To amend the Higher Education Act of 1965 to prohibit recognized accrediting agencies and associations from requiring, encouraging, or coercing institutions of higher education to meet any political litmus test or violate any right protected by the Constitution as a condition of accreditation."

The Chair announced that the unfinished business was the question on the motion to recommit H.R. 3724, passage of H.R. 3724, if ordered, the motion to recommit H.R. 4790, and passage of H.R. 4790, if ordered, which had all been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of September 19.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.

At the conclusion of debate on H.R. 4790, the Chair put the question on the motion to recommit and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Huizenga demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question on the motion to recommit was ordered pursuant to clause 2(b) of rule XIX.
Mr. Casten moved to recommit to the Committee on Financial Services.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 4790.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 3724, H.R. 4790, H.R. 5179, H.R. 5339, H.R. 5717, H.R. 7909 and H.J. Res. 136. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 3724 and H.R. 5717 under a structured rule and H.R. 4790, H.R. 5179, H.R. 5339, H.R. 7909, and H.J. Res. 136 under a closed rule. The resolution provides for one hour of general debate and one motion to recommit on each measure.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 1455. H.R. 4790 — "To amend the Federal securities laws with respect to the materiality of disclosure requirements, to establish the Public Company Advisory Committee, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate on H.R. 3724, the Chair put the question on the motion to recommit and by voice vote announced that the noes had prevailed. Ms. Bonamici demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question on the motion to recommit was ordered pursuant to clause 2(b) of rule XIX.
Ms. Bonamici moved to recommit to the Committee on Education and the Workforce.
The House adopted the amendments en gros as agreed to by the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House rose from the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union to report H.R. 3724.
On agreeing to the Ogles amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1455, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Ogles amendment No. 3.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Ogles,  numbered 3 printed in Part A of House Report 118-685 to specify that the prohibition on discrimination by public universities against religious student organizations based on their leadership standards includes leadership standards regarding religious identity, belief, or practice.
On agreeing to the Ogles amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1455, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Ogles amendment No. 2.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Ogles,  numbered 2 printed in Part A of House Report 118-685 to express the sense of Congress that acts of violence committed on the campus of an institution of higher education are not protected under the First Amendment to the Constitution.
On agreeing to the Molinaro amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1455, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Molinaro amendment No. 1.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Molinaro,  numbered 1 printed in Part A of House Report 118-685 to add "religion" to the definition of political test in the bill.
The Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of general debate on H.R. 3724.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Michael Guest to act as Chairman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 1455 and Rule XVIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 3724, H.R. 4790, H.R. 5179, H.R. 5339, H.R. 5717, H.R. 7909 and H.J. Res. 136. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 3724 and H.R. 5717 under a structured rule and H.R. 4790, H.R. 5179, H.R. 5339, H.R. 7909, and H.J. Res. 136 under a closed rule. The resolution provides for one hour of general debate and one motion to recommit on each measure.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 1455. H.R. 3724 — "To amend the Higher Education Act of 1965 to prohibit recognized accrediting agencies and associations from requiring, encouraging, or coercing institutions of higher education to meet any political litmus test or violate any right protected by the Constitution as a condition of accreditation."
The House proceeded with one minute speeches which by direction of the Chair, would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. Thompson of PA to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of September 19.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 12:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Celeste Maloy to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
